862:
<image>
<title>Family Photo of Ahn Jung-geun</title>
<summary>This historical photograph, taken on October 27, 1909, at the Japanese Consulate in Vladivostok, features Ahn Jung-geun's family: his wife, Kim Ah-ryeo, and their two sons, Bundo and Jun-sang. Following Ahn's arrest by Japanese police in Harbin, his family was released after three days without charges. Despite attempts to visit him in prison, Kim was denied access, and Ahn only received this photograph, which he cherished until his death. After Ahn's execution, his family chose to remain in the Russian Far East rather than return to their homeland.</summary>
<entities>

<title>Yongsan Station Historical Overview</title>
<summary>Yongsan Station was completed in November 1906 as a three-story wooden building but was destroyed by fire and subsequently rebuilt. Lee Bong-chang, who passed the railway department's examination, was employed at the train connection section, which was a dangerous job with risks of serious injury or death from small mistakes. Despite becoming skilled at his work, Lee faced dissatisfaction due to unfair treatment and promotion discrimination, as promotions were given to Japanese individuals while he, as a Korean, experienced discrimination.</summary>
